revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} '''British official war artists''' were a select group of artists who were employed on contract, or commissioned to produce specific works during the [[First World War]], the [[Second World War]] and select military actions in the post-war period.<ref name="tolson_cwm">Tolson, Roger. [http://www.warmuseum.ca/cwm/exhibitions/artwar/essays/britain_war_artists_scheme_e.shtml "A Common Cause: Britain's War Artists Scheme."] Canadian War Museum, 2005.</ref> Official war artists have been appointed by governments for information or propaganda purposes and to record events on the battlefield;<ref>[[The National Archives|National Archives (UK)]], [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/theartofwar/inf3.htm "'The Art of War,' Learn About the Art."]</ref> but there are many other types of war artist.
A [[war artist]] will have depicted some aspect of war through art; this might be a pictorial record or it might commemorate how war shapes lives.<ref name="iwm_about">[[Imperial War Museum]] (IWM), [http://www.iwm.org.uk/server/show/nav.604 About the Imperial War Museum]</ref> A war artist creates a visual account of war by showing its impact as men and women are shown waiting, preparing, fighting, suffering and celebrating.<ref name="cwmartists">[[Canadian War Museum]] (CWM), [http://www.civilization.ca/cwm/exhibitions/artwar/introduction_e.shtml "Australia, Britain and Canada in the Second World War,"] 2005.</ref>
The works produced by war artists illustrate and record many aspects of war, and the individual's experience of war, whether allied or enemy, service or civilian, military or political, social or cultural. The rôle of the artist and his work embraces the causes, course and consequences of conflict and it has an essentially educational purpose.<ref name="iwm_about"/>
==First World War== [[File:The Kensingtons at Laventie (1915) (Art.IWM ART 15661).jpg|thumb|''[[The Kensingtons at Laventie]]'' (1915)]] Throughout the early years of the First World War, the British Government did not support an official war artist scheme. This began to change after artists who had served on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]], such as [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]] and [[Christopher R. W. Nevinson]] exhibited paintings based on their experiences in France.<ref name="WW1Art">{{cite book|author=|publisher=Imperial War Museums|year=2008|title=Art from the First World War|ISBN=978-1-904897-98-9}}</ref> The public acclaim that [[Eric Kennington]] received when his painting ''[[The Kensingtons at Laventie]]'' was first exhibited in London in April 1916 prompted [[Charles Frederick Gurney Masterman|Charles Masterman]], head of the [[Wellington House|British War Propaganda Bureau]], acting on the advice of [[William Rothenstein]], to appoint [[Muirhead Bone]] as Britain's first official war artist in May 1916. After Bone returned to England he was replaced by his brother-in-law, [[Francis Dodd (artist)|Francis Dodd]], who had been working for the ''[[Manchester Guardian]]''. In 1917 arrangements were made to send other artists to France including Kennington, Nash, Nevinson, [[William Orpen]] and [[William Rothenstein]]. [[John Lavery]] and others were recruited to paint pictures of the home front.<ref name="Harries">{{cite book|author1=Merion Harries |author2=Susie Harries |publisher=Michael Joseph, The Imperial War Museum & the Tate Gallery|year=1983|title=The War Artists, British Official War Art of the Twentieth Century |ISBN=0 7181 2314 X}}</ref>
Early in 1918, responsibility for the British war artists was passed to the [[British War Memorials Committee]], BWMC, when the Department of Information became the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] with [[Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]] as its Minister.<ref name="USmalley">{{cite web |author=Ulrike Smalley|url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/history/how-the-british-government-sponsored-the-arts-in-the-first-world-war |title=How The British Government Sponsored The Arts In The First World War |date=|accessdate=28 September 2016|work=Imperial War Museum}}</ref> Rather than focus on short-term propaganda, the main aim of the BMWC was to create a lasting memorial to the war in the form of a national [[Hall of Remembrance]]. To this end younger artists, including [[Stanley Spencer]] and [[Wyndham Lewis]], were commissioned by the BWMC to produce a series of large artworks, After the War, when the BWMC was wound up, this series of artworks, which included ''[[The Menin Road (painting)|The Menin Road]]'' by Paul Nash and ''[[Gassed (painting)|Gassed]]'' by [[John Singer Sargent]], became part of the [[Imperial War Museum]] collection.<ref name="Gough">{{cite book|author=Paul Gough|publisher=Sansom and Company|year=2010|title=A Terrible Beauty: British Artists in the First World War |ISBN=978-1-906593-00-1}}</ref>
==Second World War== The British War Advisory Scheme (WAS) was administered by the [[War Artists' Advisory Committee]], WAAC, of the Ministry of Information. The project was devised and run by [[Kenneth Clark]], Director of the [[National Gallery]].<ref name="tolson_cwm"/> When the committee was dissolved in December 1945 its collection consisted of 5,570 works of art produced by over four hundred artists, who had been employed on either full-time contracts, short-term contracts or commissions for individual works.<ref name=NPGwaac>{{cite web |author=National Portrait Gallery|url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/group/1130/World%20War%20II:%20Official%20War%20Artists|title=World War II: Official War Artists |year=|accessdate=29 February 2016|work=National Portrait Gallery}}</ref>
==Selected artists== {{dynamic list}}
===First World War=== {{div col|colwidth=20em}}
*[[Anna Airy]], (1882–1964) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/106 |title=A Shell Forge at a National Projectile Factory, Hackney Marshes, London, 1918 [Art.IWM ART 4032] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref><ref name=Independent>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/women-at-war-the-female-british-artists-who-were-written-out-of-history-2264670.html |title=Women at war: The female British artists who were written out of history |date=8 April 2011 |publisher=[[The Independent]] }}</ref> *[[David Bomberg]], 1890–1957).<ref>{{cite web |author=[[Imperial War Museum]] |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?f%5B0%5D=makerString%3ABomberg%2C%20David&query= |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by David Bomberg }}</ref> *[[Muirhead Bone]], 1876–1953.<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3ABone%2C%20Muirhead&items_per_page=50 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by Muirhead Bone }}</ref> *[[Frank Brangwyn]], 1867–1956.<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3ABrangwyn%2C%20Frank&items_per_page=50 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by Frank Brangwyn }}</ref> *[[George Clausen]], 1852–1944.<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3AClausen%2C%20George&items_per_page=50 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by George Clausen }}</ref> *[[Olive Edis]], 1876–1955.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwmcollections.org.uk/dbtw-wpd/exec/dbtwpub.dll?AC=NEXT_RECORD&XC=/dbtw-wpd/exec/dbtwpub.dll&BU=http://www.iwmcollections.org.uk/qryImages.php&TN=Uncat&SN=AUTO22814&SE=1196&RN=9&MR=25&TR=0&TX=1000&ES=0&CS=1&XP=&RF=salResultsThumb&EF=&DF=salDetails&RL=0&EL=0&DL=0&NP=1&ID=&MF=WPENGMSG.INI&MQ=&TI=0&DT=&ST=0&IR=0&NR=0&NB=0&SV=0&BG=0&FG=0&QS= |title=Olive Edis |publisher=Iwmcollections.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> *[[Colin Gill]], 1892–1940. *[[Adrian Hill]], 1895–1977. *[[Francis Ernest Jackson]], 1872–1945 *[[Augustus John]], 1878–1961.<ref>[http://www.world-war-pictures.com/index.htm World War Pictures], [http://www.world-war-pictures.com/war-artist-augustus-john.htm Augustus John, war artist]</ref> *[[Eric Kennington]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1888–1960.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/15123 |title=Gassed and Wounded [Art.IWM ART 4744] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> *[[Wyndham Lewis]], 1882–1957.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/16688 |title=A Battery Shelled [Art.IWM ART 2747] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}} </ref> *[[John Hodgson Lobley]], 1878–1954.<ref name=BBC>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/artists/john-hodgson-lobley/paintings/slideshow |title=John Hodgson Lobley, 1878–1954 |publisher=BBC / [[The Public Catalogue Foundation]] }}</ref> *[[Fortunino Matania]]<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3AMatania%2C%20Fortunino&items_per_page=50 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by Fortunino Matania }}; Italian artist working in Britain.</ref> *[[John Nash (artist)|John Nash]], 1893–1977.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/20015 |title='Over The Top'. 1st Artists' Rifles at Marcoing, 30th December 1917 [Art.IWM ART 1656] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> *[[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], 1889–1946.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/20087 |title=The Menin Road [Art.IWM ART 2242] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> *[[Christopher R. W. Nevinson]] *[[Herbert Arnould Olivier]], 1861–1952. *[[William Orpen|Sir William Orpen]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1878–1931;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/20882 |title=Harvest, 1918 [Art.IWM ART 4663] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> *[[William Rothenstein]], 1872–1945.<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&items_per_page=50&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3ARothenstein%2C%20William%20%28Sir%29 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by William Rothenstein}}</ref> *[[Austin Spare]], 1886–1956.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-war-pictures.com/war-artist-austin-spare.htm |title=Austin Spare, war artist |publisher=World-war-pictures.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> *[[Gerald Spencer Pryse]], 1882–1956.<ref>{{cite web |author=Imperial War Museum |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search?query=&f%5b0%5d=makerString%3APryse%2C%20Gerald%20Spencer%20%28MC%29&items_per_page=50 |year=2013 |accessdate=13 March 2013 |work=IWM Collections Search |title=Works by Gerald Spencer Pryse }}</ref> *[[Snaffles]] (Charles Johnson Payne) *[[Leonard Campbell Taylor]], 1874–1969 *[[Sir Stanley Spencer]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1891–1959.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/25132 |title=Travoys Arriving with Wounded at a Dressing-Station at Smol, Macedonia, September 1916, 1919 [Art.IWM ART 2268] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=12 Nov 2013}}; also a war artist in World War II.</ref>
{{div col end}}
===Second World War=== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Edward Ardizzone]] [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1900–1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilization.ca/cwm/exhibitions/artwar/artists/edward-ardizzone_e.shtml |title=Edward Ardizzone |language=fr |publisher=Civilization.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> * [[Edward Bawden]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1903–1989.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilization.ca/cwm/exhibitions/artwar/artists/edward-bawden_e.shtml |title=Edward Bawden |language=fr |publisher=Civilization.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-07-15}}</ref> * [[Stephen Bone]] 1904–1958 * [[David Bomberg]] 1890–1957 * [[Henry Carr (artist)|Henry Carr]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1894–1970 * [[Leslie Cole (artist)|Leslie Cole]], 1910–1976 * [[Charles Cundall]], 1890–1971 * [[Evelyn Mary Dunbar]] * [[Simon Elwes]], 1902–1975 * [[Barnett Freedman]] * [[Ethel Gabain]], 1882–1950 * [[Charles Ginner]] * [[Duncan Grant]], 1885–1978 * [[Thomas Hennell]], 1903–1945 * [[Eliot Hodgkin]], 1905–1987 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/13274 |title=Eliot Hodgkin |publisher=Imperial War Museums |date= |accessdate=2012-09-16}}</ref> * Eric Kennington, [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1888–1960. * [[Mary Kessell]], 1914–1977.<ref name=iwm_Kessell>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/15246 |title=Refugees: Mother and Child |publisher=Imperial War Museums |date= |accessdate=2012-02-29}}</ref> * [[Laura Knight]] [[Order of the British Empire|DBE]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1877–1970.<ref name=Independent /> * [[L.S. Lowry]] * [[Henry Moore]] * [[James Morris (artist)|James Morris]] * Paul Nash, 1889–1946. * [[Cuthbert Orde]], 1888–1968 * [[Mervyn Peake]], 1911–1968 * [[John Piper (artist)|John Piper]] * [[Vivian Pitchforth|Roland Vivian Pitchforth]], 1895–1982 * [[Eric Ravilious]], 1903–1942 * [[Albert Richards (artist)|Albert Richards]], 1919–1945 * [[Leonard Rosoman]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1913–2012 * [[William Rothenstein]], 1872–1945. * [[Alan Sorrell]], 1904–1974. * [[Ruskin Spear]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1911–1990 * Stanley Spencer [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1891–1959.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/25164 |title=Shipbuilding on the Clyde: Bending the Keel Plate, 1943 [Art.IWM ART LD 3106] |author=Imperial War Museum |work=IWM Collections Search |accessdate=12 Nov 2013}}</ref> * [[Graham Sutherland]] [[Order of Merit|OM]], 1903–1980 * [[Carel Weight]] [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[Royal Academy|RA]], 1908–1997 * [[Frank Wootton (artist)|Frank Wootton]], 1914–1998 * [[Doris Zinkeisen]], 1898–1991 * [[Anna Zinkeisen]], 1901–1976 {{div col end}} [[File:Garvaghy road on July 1997.jpg|250px|thumbnail|"Drumcree, The Garvaghy Road July 1997" by David Rowlands, [[oil on canvas]], 91cm x 61cm]]
===Recent conflicts=== *[[Peter Howson]], b. 1958 <ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-Intro>{{cite web |url=http://archive.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.909 |accessdate=29 June 2012 |title=Contemporary War Artists: Introduction |publisher=[[Imperial War Museum]] }}</ref><ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-PH>{{cite web |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090106051558/http://collections.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.912 |archivedate=6 January 2009 |accessdate=21 April 2013 |url=http://collections.iwm.org.uk/server.php?show=ConWebDoc.912 |title=Contemporary War Artists: Peter Howson: Bosnia |publisher=[[Imperial War Museum]] }}</ref> *[[John Keane (artist)|John Keane]], b. 1954 <ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-Intro /><ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-JK>{{cite web |url=http://archive.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.2481 |title= Contemporary War Artists: John Keane: The Gulf War |publisher=[[Imperial War Museum]] |accessdate=29 June 2012 }}</ref> *[[Linda Kitson]], b. 1945 <ref name=Independent /><ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-Intro /><ref name=IWM-WWA-CWA-LK>{{cite web |accessdate=29 June 2012 |url=http://archive.iwm.org.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.2478 |title=Contemporary War Artists: Linda Kitson: The Falklands War |publisher=[[Imperial War Museum]] }}</ref> *[[David Rowlands (artist)|David Rowlands]]: Military painter, only artist invited by the British Army to take part of [[Operation Granby]].<ref>[http://www.directart.co.uk/mall/artist.php?ArtistID=144 David Rowlands]</ref> *[[Derek Eland]]: b.1961 (Afghanistan 2011)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history%20%26%20heritage/war%20%26%20conflict/modern%20conflict/art364882 |title=In our own Words: Soldiers share their thoughts on war in Afghanistan at Imperial War Museum |author=Owen, Nick |date=26 September 2011 |publisher=Culture24.org.uk |accessdate=29 June 2012}}</ref> *[[Alixandra Fazzina]]: b. 1974 (Bosnia 1995)<ref name=foreman>{{cite news|last1=Foreman|first1=Jonathan|title=Alixandra Fazzina: Witness to the devastation|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/7999716/Alixandra-Fazzina-Witness-to-the-devastation.html|accessdate=6 May 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=13 September 2010}}</ref>

== References == * McCloskey, Barbara. (2005). ''Artists of World War II.'' Westport: Greenwood Press. ISBN 9780313321535; {{OCLC|475496457}}
==Further reading== * Gallatin, Albert Eugene. ''[https://archive.org/details/artandgreatwar00gallgoog Art and the Great War]''. (New York: E.P. Dutton, 1919). * Harrington, Peter. ''British Artists and War: The Face of Battle in Paintings and Prints, 1700–1914.'' (London: Greenhill, 1993). ISBN 1-85367-157-6 * Haycock, David Boyd. "A Crisis of Brilliance: Five Young British Artists and the Great War." (London: Old Street Publishing). * Hichberger, J.W.M. (1988). ''Images of the Army: The Military in British Art 1815–1914''. Manchester: University Press. * Knott, Richard, ''The Sketchbook War.'' The History Press, 2013. * Sillars, Stuart (1987). ''Art and Survival in First World War Britain''. Basingstoke: Macmillan. *Holme, Charles. ''[https://archive.org/details/wardepictedbydis00holmuoft The war depicted by distinguished British artists]'' (''[[The Studio (magazine)|The Studio]]'' Ltd., 1918).
==External links== * [[Ministry of Defence (UK)]] (MOD), [http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/AboutDefence/WhatWeDo/DefenceEstateandEnvironment/MODArtCollection/MinistryOfDefenceArtCollectionWarArtists.htm MOD art collection, war artists] * [[National Archives (UK)]][http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/theartofwar/ The Art of War] at The National Archives * [http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/search Imperial War Museum Collections], many examples of the work of British war artists can be found online here.
